",n(s.li,{children:"Initialize Variables: We initialize a dummy head node, which simplifies appending new nodes to the result list. Variables n1, n2, and carry are used to store values from the linked lists and any carry-over during addition."}),"
",n(s.li,{children:"Iterating Through Lists: We loop until all nodes in both lists are processed and the carry is zero. At each iteration, we extract values from the lists or use 0 if a list is exhausted. Then, we compute the sum and update the carry for the next iteration."}),"

title: Binary Search
description: Solve the Binary Search problem efficiently using Go.
body:
const{Fragment:e,jsx:n,jsxs:l}=arguments[0];function _createMdxContent(i){const t={a:"a",code:"code",figure:"figure",h2:"h2",h3:"h3",li:"li",ol:"ol",p:"p",pre:"pre",span:"span",strong:"strong",ul:"ul",...i.components};return l(e,{children:[n(t.h2,{id:"problem-statement",children:n(t.a,{className:"subheading-anchor","aria-label":"Link to section",href:"#problem-statement",children:"Problem Statement"})}),"
",n(t.p,{children:"The goal is to implement a binary search algorithm that efficiently finds the index of a specified key in a sorted list of integers. If the key is found, the function should return its index; if not, it should return -1."}),"
",n(t.h2,{id:"approach",children:n(t.a,{className:"subheading-anchor","aria-label":"Link to section",href:"#approach",children:"Approach"})}),"
",n(t.p,{children:"Binary search is a classic algorithm that works on the principle of divide and conquer. description: Solve the BOB problem efficiently using Go.

",n(r.p,{children:"In the BOB problem, Bob is a lackadaisical teenager. He responds to conversation based on specific patterns in the input string. Bob answers based on the following rules:"}),"
",i(r.ul,{children:["
",n(r.li,{children:'If you ask him a question (i.e., the remark ends with a question mark), he answers "Sure."'}),"
",n(r.li,{children:'If you yell at him (i.e., all letters in the remark are uppercase), he answers "Whoa, chill out!"'}),"
",n(r.li,{children:'If you yell a question at him, he answers "Calm down, I know what I'm doing!"'}),"
",n(r.li,{children:'If you address him without saying anything (i.e., the remark is empty or consists only of whitespace), he responds with "Fine. Be that way!"'}),"
",n(r.li,{children:'For anything else, he responds with "Whatever."'}),"
"]}),"
",n(r.h2,{id:"approach",children:n(r.a,{className:"subheading-anchor","aria-label":"Link to section",href:"#approach",children:"Approach"})}),"

",i(r.li,{children:[n(r.strong,{children:"Trim whitespace"}),": Remove leading and trailing whitespace from the input string."]}),"

title: Crypto Square
description: Solve the Crypto Square problem efficiently using Go.
body:
const{Fragment:n,jsx:l,jsxs:e}=arguments[0];function _createMdxContent(r){const c={a:"a",code:"code",figure:"figure",h2:"h2",h3:"h3",li:"li",ol:"ol",p:"p",pre:"pre",span:"span",strong:"strong",ul:"ul",...r.components};return e(n,{children:[l(c.h2,{id:"problem-statement",children:l(c.a,{className:"subheading-anchor","aria-label":"Link to section",href:"#problem-statement",children:"Problem Statement"})}),"
",e(c.p,{children:["The ",l(c.strong,{children:"Crypto Square"})," problem involves encoding a string into a square grid format, known as a cryptosquare. ",e(s.p,{children:["The ",l(s.strong,{children:"Custom Set"})," problem requires implementing a collection of unique string values. The goal is to create a set data structure that allows adding, checking, and performing operations like union, intersection, and difference on sets of strings."]}),"

",e(s.li,{children:[l(s.strong,{children:"Subset(s1, s2)"}),": Check if one set is a subset of another."]}),"
",e(s.li,{children:[l(s.strong,{children:"Disjoint(s1, s2)"}),": Check if two sets have no elements in common."]}),"
",e(s.li,{children:[l(s.strong,{children:"Equal(s1, s2)"}),": Check if two sets contain the same elements."]}),"
",e(s.li,{children:[l(s.strong,{children:"Intersection(s1, s2)"}),": Return a new set containing elements present in both sets."]}),"
",e(s.li,{children:[l(s.strong,{children:"Difference(s1, s2)"}),": Return a new set containing elements in the first set but not in the second."]}),"
",e(s.li,{children:[l(s.strong,{children:"Union(s1, s2)"}),": Return a new set containing all elements from both sets."]}),"

",l(r.p,{children:["In the ",n(r.strong,{children:"Interest is Interesting"})," problem, the task is to compute interest on a balance, update the balance annually, and determine how many years it will take to reach a desired balance. The calculations are based on dynamic interest rates depending on the current balance."]}),"

"]}),"

",l(r.li,{children:[n(r.strong,{children:"Interest"}),": This function multiplies the balance by the interest rate to calculate the annual interest."]}),"
",l(r.li,{children:[n(r.strong,{children:"AnnualBalanceUpdate"}),": This function adds the interest to the balance to calculate the updated balance after a year."]}),"
",l(r.li,{children:[n(r.strong,{children:"YearsBeforeDesiredBalance"}),": This function repeatedly applies the annual balance update until the target balance is reached, counting the number of years."]}),"

"]}),"
"]}),"
",l(r.li,{children:["

",l(r.ul,{children:["
",n(r.li,{children:"Add the interest to the current balance to update it for the year."}),"

"]}),"
",l(r.li,{children:["

title: Largest Series Product

body:

",e(i.p,{children:"The Largest Series Product problem involves finding the maximum product of a contiguous subsequence of digits from a given string. The length of this subsequence is determined by a specified span. If the span is greater than the length of the string or if it is negative, an error should be returned. Additionally, if the string contains non-digit characters, an error should also be raised."}),"

",e(i.li,{children:"Convert the string of digits into a slice of bytes, validating that all characters are numeric."}),"
"]}),"

description: A comprehensive guide on how to implement Apache Kafka using Golang and Docker, showcasing a simple order processing system.

title: Understanding NATS with Golang and Docker
description: A comprehensive guide on how to implement NATS using Golang and Docker, showcasing a simple order processing system.

",l(s.p,{children:"NATS is a high-performance messaging system that facilitates communication in microservices, distributed systems, and cloud-native applications. We’ll also build a simple order processing system as an example."}),"

",l(s.p,{children:"NATS is a simple, secure, and scalable cloud-native messaging system. It supports messaging patterns like Publish-Subscribe (Pub/Sub), Request-Reply, and Load Balancing, making it an excellent tool for building distributed applications. Its low-latency communication makes it ideal for real-time systems."}),"

",e(s.li,{children:[l(s.strong,{children:"Publish/Subscribe"}),": One-to-many communication, where publishers send messages to multiple subscribers."]}),"
",e(s.li,{children:[l(s.strong,{children:"Request/Reply"}),": One-to-one messaging, where the requestor expects a response."]}),"
",e(s.li,{children:[l(s.strong,{children:"Persistence and Queueing"}),": NATS JetStream adds persistence, making it suitable for scenarios requiring durability."]}),"
",e(s.li,{children:[l(s.strong,{children:"Ease of Use"}),": It offers a simple setup and client libraries for many languages, including Golang."]}),"

title: Implementing RabbitMQ with Golang and Docker
description: A step-by-step guide to using RabbitMQ in a Golang-based microservices architecture, demonstrating order processing with Docker.

",n(s.p,{children:"RabbitMQ is one of the most popular open-source message brokers that provides reliable, asynchronous messaging between services. In this guide, we will walk through how to integrate RabbitMQ with a Golang-based microservices architecture and containerize the setup using Docker. To demonstrate its usage, we’ll build a simple order processing system."}),"
",n(s.h3,{id:"what-youll-learn",children:n(s.a,{className:"subheading-anchor","aria-label":"Link to section",href:"#what-youll-learn",children:"What You'll Learn:"})}),"

",e(s.p,{children:["RabbitMQ is a message broker that facilitates communication between microservices or between different parts of an application. It supports various messaging patterns, including ",n(s.strong,{children:"Publish-Subscribe"}),", ",n(s.strong,{children:"Work Queues"}),", ",n(s.strong,{children:"Routing"}),", and ",n(s.strong,{children:"Topics"}),". RabbitMQ is highly reliable, providing message persistence, delivery acknowledgments, and fault tolerance, making it suitable for distributed systems."]}),"
",n(s.h3,{id:"key-features-of-rabbitmq",children:n(s.a,{className:"subheading-anchor","aria-label":"Link to section",href:"#key-features-of-rabbitmq",children:"Key Features of RabbitMQ:"})}),"
",e(s.ul,{children:["
",e(s.li,{children:[n(s.strong,{children:"Exchange Types"}),": It supports multiple exchange types, like direct, topic, and fanout, to handle different routing mechanisms."]}),"
",e(s.li,{children:[n(s.strong,{children:"Queues"}),": Messages are delivered to queues and then consumed by subscribers."]}),"
",e(s.li,{children:[n(s.strong,{children:"Acknowledgments"}),": Consumers can send acknowledgments after processing messages, ensuring message reliability."]}),"
",e(s.li,{children:[n(s.strong,{children:"Persistence"}),": Messages can be persisted to avoid loss in case of failures."]}),"
",e(s.li,{children:[n(s.strong,{children:"Scalability"}),": Supports clustering for high availability and load balancing."]}),"
"]}),"
",n(s.hr,{}),"

",e(s.li,{children:[n(s.strong,{children:"Entry Struct"}),": The Entry struct represents a financial entry with fields for date, description, and change amount in cents."]}),"
",e(s.li,{children:[n(s.strong,{children:"FormatLedger Function"}),": This function processes the list of entries, sorts them, and formats them according to the specified locale and currency. It also uses channels for concurrent processing of entry formatting."]}),"
",e(s.li,{children:[n(s.strong,{children:"Error Handling"}),": The function includes error handling to manage incorrect date formats and unsupported locales."]}),"

",n(s.h3,{id:"time-and-space-complexity",children:n(s.a,{className:"subheading-anchor","aria-label":"Link to section",href:"#time-and-space-complexity",children:"Time and Space Complexity"})}),"
",e(s.ul,{children:["
",e(s.li,{children:[n(s.strong,{children:"Time Complexity"}),": The sorting operation has a time complexity of O(n log n) where n is the number of entries. Formatting and validation may add additional linear complexity."]}),"
",e(s.li,{children:[n(s.strong,{children:"Space Complexity"}),": The space complexity is O(n) due to the need to store formatted strings and the use of a channel for concurrency."]}),"
"]}),"

Tracking the Longest Substring: At each step, we calculate the length of the current valid substring and keep track of the maximum length found so far."}),"

At each step, we update the result with the length of the current substring if it's the longest we've seen so far."}),"

",n(c.li,{children:"For closing brackets, we verify if the stack is not empty and if the top of the stack matches the current closing bracket. If they match, we pop the top element from the stack."}),"
",n(c.li,{children:"At the end of the iteration, if the stack is empty, it indicates all brackets were matched correctly; otherwise, some brackets are unmatched."}),"
"]}),"
",n(c.h3,{id:"time-and-space-complexity",children:n(c.a,{className:"subheading-anchor","aria-label":"Link to section",href:"#time-and-space-complexity",children:"Time and Space Complexity"})}),"
",l(c.ul,{children:["
",l(c.li,{children:[n(c.strong,{children:"Time Complexity"}),": O(n), where n is the length of the input string. We traverse the string once, performing constant time operations for each character."]}),"
",l(c.li,{children:[n(c.strong,{children:"Space Complexity"}),": O(n) in the worst case, where all characters are opening brackets, and they are stored in the stack."]}),"
"]}),"
",n(c.h2,{id:"conclusion",children:n(c.a,{className:"subheading-anchor","aria-label":"Link to section",href:"#conclusion",children:"Conclusion"})}),"
",n(c.p,{children:"The Matching Brackets problem can be efficiently solved using a stack-based approach. This method allows us to keep track of opening brackets and ensures that all brackets in the input string are correctly matched and nested. The solution is both time-efficient and space-efficient, making it suitable for practical applications in parsing expressions or validating input formats."})]})}return{default:function(e={}){const{wrapper:l}=e.components||{};return l?n(l,{...e,children:n(_createMdxContent,{...e})}):_createMdxContent(e)}};
